from six citizens (Petition No. EN6430)
Pensions and Benefits

When families receive a lump sum payment on 30 June, it is deeply unjust that Services Australia does not investigate the circumstances behind this income boost but instead proceeds to reclaim any funds they consider overpaid in family tax benefits for that financial year. This approach fails to account for the complexities of individual financial situations, potentially penalising hardworking middle-income Australians who may have legitimate reasons for the sudden increase in income. Fairness demands a thorough assessment of the reasons behind such changes before implementing clawbacks, ensuring that families are not unfairly burdened by administrative decisions that overlook their unique circumstances. The legislation must reflect the current socioeconomic climate and the challenges faced by families striving to maintain financial stability. Legislation should ensure fairness and consider the diverse circumstances of recipients, promoting a supportive framework that genuinely assists families in need without imposing undue hardship.

We therefore ask the House to urgently review and update the current family tax benefits legislation, to particularly scrutinize the application of 'special circumstances' to include sudden changes in income such as termination payment or unexpected financial income within a time frame close to the end of financial year and to apply an equitable approach by pro-rating the income test.
from 86 citizens (Petition No. EN6431)
Australian Curriculum: Financial Literacy

The critical need for mandatory financial literacy education in the national school curriculum, developed and delivered by qualified professionals from the Financial Counselling Association Australia (FCA).

We therefore ask the House to edge: Financial literacy is a fundamental human right. It is essential for individuals to have sound knowledge of navigating financial matters, as financial decisions impact nearly every aspect of adult life.

Equipping Young People for Life: Current educational curricula often overlook practical financial skills. Integrating financial literacy into schools equips young people with essential skills for life outside of school, including budgeting, saving, understanding credit, and managing debt.

Reducing Unmanageable Debt: Educated citizens are less likely to accumulate unmanageable debt. By understanding financial principles from a young age, students can make informed financial decisions, reducing the likelihood of financial crises.

Awareness of Financial Counsellors: Including financial literacy in the curriculum will increase awareness of financial counsellors and the free services they provide. Early intervention and advice can prevent financial difficulties from escalating, benefiting individuals and society.

Overall Financial Health of Australians: Enhancing financial literacy across the population will lead to broader economic benefits, including reduced personal debt levels and a more financially resilient citizenry.
Your Petitioners Therefore Request That the House:

Mandate the inclusion of financial literacy in the national school curriculum, with the Financial Counselling Association Australia responsible for developing and delivering the content through qualified financial counsellors and capability workers.

from five citizens (Petition No. EN6436)
Domestic and Family Violence

As a high-risk domestic violence survivor, I understand all too well the dire consequences of not knowing a partner's violent past. Often, the perpetrators of this abuse expertly craft their victims as the abusers, thereby gaining sympathy, attention, and defending themselves with an army of enablers.

Imagine living in a society where potential victims could find out if their current or prospective partner has a history of domestic violence beforehand. We would be better equipped to protect ourselves, and potentially save countless lives. This is the purpose of Clare's Law, a domestic violence disclosure scheme.
Unfortunately, this lifesaving piece of legislation is yet to be adopted nationwide in Australia.

The Australian Bureau of Statistics (2016) reported that at least one woman a week is killed by a partner or former partner in Australia; this indicates the urgent need for preventative measures like Clare's Law. The law is not about controlling or restricting individuals but about empowering them with information to make informed decisions about their lives.

We must advocate for Clare's Law in every state and territory in Australia, transforming this urgent call into legislative reality that could save lives. Stand with us. Stand for a safer Australia. Please, sign this petition for the implementation of Clare's Law across our nation.
We therefore ask the House to support the implementation of "Clares Law" in every state of Australia. Stand with us. Save lives.

Since the onset of the pandemic in 2020, the lives of migrant workers, International Students, and Temporary Visa Holders in Australia have been profoundly affected. from 109 citizens (Petition No. EN6443)
International Students

International students have long been viewed primarily as a financial asset and workforce in Australia, with the international education sector bringing in a staggering $40.3 billion annually and supporting 250,000 jobs. This revenue is generated through student fees, accommodation costs, utilities, childcare expenses, and the students labor contributions. In essence, international education is a major industry. These students are left to fend for themselves against rising tuition fees, exploitative landlords, and unscrupulous education agents. They are often forced to cover essential expenses such as childcare and healthcare out of their own pockets. The issue of wage theft among international students is widespread and deeply ingrained in the system. During the COVID-19 pandemic, the government allowed international students unlimited work hours without risking visa cancellation. This decision was made because Australia heavily relied on international students to navigate through the pandemic. International students took on roles such as stocking shelves in supermarkets, making deliveries, and working in kitchens, providing vital support to Australia during the challenging times of the pandemic for three years. However, from July 1, 2023, international students are restricted to working a maximum of 48 hours per fortnight.

We therefore ask the House to abolish the restriction on work hours for international students. This policy has proven to be successful, reasonable, and has enabled students to participate in the workforce on an equal basis with others. With the work-hour limit lifted, there has been no indication of students dropping out of their courses.

from four citizens (Petition No. EN6448)
Gambling

We, the undersigned, believe that legalizing and regulating online poker in Australia would provide significant economic and social benefits. Online poker is distinct from other forms of gambling as it is a game of skill and strategy, rather than pure chance. Legalization would ensure a safe, regulated environment, protecting players from unregulated and potentially harmful offshore sites. This would also generate tax revenue for essential public services and allow for effective implementation of responsible gambling measures.

Furthermore, legalizing online poker would provide a valuable entertainment option for Australians living in rural and remote areas, who often lack easy access to physical casinos. This accessibility ensures that all Australians can enjoy the game safely and responsibly, regardless of their geographical location. Since the Interactive Gambling Act 2001 (IGA) has made it an offense to provide or advertise prohibited interactive gambling services to customers in Australia, many Australians have turned to offshore operators that provide limited harm minimization and consumer protections. Legalizing online poker within Australia would enable the government to implement comprehensive consumer protection measures and integrate online poker within the National Consumer Protection Framework for online wagering, which aims to minimize the risk of gambling harm to Australian consumers.

We therefore ask the House to take legislative action to legalize and regulate online poker in Australia. This includes establishing a comprehensive regulatory framework that ensures consumer protection, implements responsible gambling practices, and generates economic benefits for public services.
from 21 citizens (Petition No. EN6452)
Senior Australians

The number of people aged over 65 years in Australia is anticipated to grow from 4.31 million in 2021 to 6.66 million by 2041, with those aged over 85 years expected to grow from 534,000 to 1.28 million over the same timeframe (a 140 per cent increase). Older Australians make important social, economic and physical contributions through paid and volunteer work, care of family members, and financial contributions to family members. from 298 citizens (Petition No. EN6456)

Fexofenadine is listed on the Repatriation Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme only. Without treatment patients can require further medication, as well as risk developing a widening range of allergens or go on to experience anaphylaxis. Where hayfever is present the risks of not treating it appropriately include going on to develop asthma- which requires further medications and is implicated in higher risk factors for COVID and other viral infections, placing burden which could be prevented on the healthcare system. Currently dosing these medications appropriately is not financially accessible for many (especially in the case of MCAS and the like where allergens may limit patients ability to safely take pharmacy brand, as well as the fact many of the further medications patients may need to take are required to be compounded). One particular dog that I care for is now so traumatised by the loud noises from the army barracks that he refuses to leave his house altogether. Another persistently claws at his door whenever these unsettling noises arise, badly hurting his paws in the process.

Our local military, while providing an essential service to our country, needs to consider the impact of their operations on the local community—in particular, our pets. Human Rights: Bangladesh

We are writing to draw your attention to the grave human rights situation currently unfolding in Bangladesh, where government forces have been employing oppressive measures and excessive force against student protesters.Thepeaceful protests have been met with violent crackdowns by the authorities, including the use of rubber bullets, tear gas, and physical assaults. Reports of arbitrary arrests, intimidation, and harassment of students have become alarmingly common, raising serious concerns about the state of democracy and human rights in the country. There have been several reports of student protesters being killed by the Police and Chatra League (student wing of the Awami League); according to some reports, the number of deaths is 50+ and rising.
We therefore ask the House to issue statements condemning the use of force against peaceful protesters and pressure the Bangladeshi government to cease its oppressive tactics.

We also urge the Australian Government to engage diplomatically with the Bangladeshi authorities to express our concerns and urge them to respect the rights of their citizens. Diplomatic pressure can be a powerful tool in promoting positive change. We also ask the Government to explore options to impose economic and travel embargo on the Government Officials in Bangladesh.
from two citizens (Petition No. EN6466)
Human Rights: Bangladesh
Since Wednesday (17 July 2024) the Government of Bangladesh headed by PM Sheik Hasina has been carrying out an indiscriminate killing of student protesters.

Over 100 students have already been killed and thousands of others are injured. The number is rising continuously. It is not possible to verify the exact number because of complete blackout of internet and electronic medias.

Bangladesh government has announced a nationwide curfew that will come into effect at the beginning of Saturday 20 July amid a telecommunications blackout. We can't communicate with our families and friends back in Bangladesh and living in serious fear of their wellbeing and safety.

The track records of Hasina regime in all form of severe human right abuses including arbitrary arrests, inhuman physical tortures and enforced disappearance of opposition activists by various law enforcement agencies, and coercions by controlled judiciaries have been well documented and published by Human Right Watch, Amnesty International, UN Human right commission and many others.

The US has already imposed targeted sanctions on former Army chief, immediate past and present inspector general of police (IGPs), Rapid action battalion (RAB)—the law enforcement agencies. Recently, the US has also enacted special visa restrictions for the close associates of the regime in ruling party, civil military bureaucracy and even in judicial services.
We therefore ask the House to
1. Stand with the Bangladeshi students and condemn the atrocities by Hasina regime.
2. Impose Australian visa restriction and complete sanction upon the Hasina regime.
from one citizen (Petition No. EN6470)
Human Rights: Bangladesh

We express our strong solidarity with the students of Bangladesh who are fighting for their fundamental rights. We are shocked and appalled and raise our grave concern that since Wednesday (17 July 2024), the Government of Bangladesh has been carrying out an indiscriminate killing of student protesters. According to all available reports, over a hundred people, most of them students, have already been killed, and thousands of others are injured. However, it is not possible to verify the exact number because of the complete blackout of the internet, all television channels and other telecommunications in Bangladesh.

The government has imposed a nationwide curfew starting Saturday, July 20th, amid a telecommunications blackout that has cut the country of approximately 170 million people off from the rest of the world as clashes between students and security forces have intensified. We can't communicate with our families and friends back in Bangladesh and live in serious fear for their well-being and safety.
We therefore ask the House to condemn the brutality of fascist government of Bangladesh and put pressure to immediately stop

severe human rights abuses, including arbitrary arrests, inhuman physical tortures, enforced disappearance of opposition activists by various law enforcement agencies and stop killing innocent students and civilians.
from two citizens (Petition No. EN6471)
Human Rights: Occupied Palestinian Territories

International Court of Justice says Israel's policies in the occupied Palestinian territory amount to annexation. The International Court of Justice (ICJ) has ruled that Israel's continued presence in the occupied Palestinian territory is unlawful and should come to an end "as rapidly as possible"
Apartheid is alive and well on the West Bank of Palestine and instituted by Israel.
We therefore ask the House to condemn Israel for it's apartheid regime in the West Bank of Palestine.
from 53 citizens (Petition No. EN6472)
Motor Sport

On the 21st of July 2024, Oscar Piastri took his maiden Formula 1 race victory at the Hungaroring in Hungary in only his second season in the sport, outperforming even F1 greats such as Lewis Hamilton and Max Verstappen.

Originating from Melbourne, Piastri was the first-ever driver to win the three championships directly below F1 consecutively as well as the first Formula 1 rookie to lead a race in over 10 years and qualify on a grand prix front row since 2010. From our very own city of Melbourne, Piastri is a generational talent in the sport and deserves to have his first win commemorated.
We therefore ask the House to make the 21st of July an annual national public holiday to commemorate this great and momentous achievement.
from 171 citizens (Petition No. EN6474)
Human Rights: Hong Kong

The Anti-Extradition Law Amendment Bill Movement in Hong Kong in 2019 further laid bare the CCP's true nature, as it violated the promises of "one country, two systems" and a high degree of autonomy for Hong Kong. This movement was met with brutal repression, covert collaboration between Chinese security officers and the Hong Kong police, and rampant violence against the people of Hong Kong. Innocent individuals were ruthlessly killed, subjected to sexual assault, or forcibly disappeared during this dark period.

We therefore ask the House to deal with the crisis in Hong Kong, the international community rightfully condemned the anti-human acts perpetrated by the Hong Kong government. Although the previous government introduced visa policies such as 485, 482, 457, and 858 for Hong Kong people holding HKSAR passports/BNO, these policies fell short in effectively addressing the humanitarian crisis faced by Hong Kong people. Their desire to seek refuge in Australia does not stem from a quest for education or employment opportunities, but rather from a desperate search for a safe haven that shares their values of freedom, democracy, and legal protection. Unfortunately, the previous government failed to provide a suitable solution to meet the needs of Hong Kong people who were facing persecution.
from 201 citizens (Petition No. EN6475)
E-Cigarettes and Vaping Products
We believe the recent ban on vapes is problematic because of the inclusion of dry-herb-vaporizers, or dry-herb-vaping devices.
There are a few methods patients and users can inhale cannabis:
1. Smoking, this includes joints/blunts, pipes, bongs/water pipes. Combustion releases smoke that contains harmful chemicals and carcinogens such as tar, carbon monoxide, and formaldehyde.
2. Oil cartridge vapes, devices that uses a cartridge that contains a liquid thc concentrate.
3. Dry-herb-vaporizers, devices that have a heating element that heats the plants until it releases vapours instead of smoke. Releases no harmful carcinogens.
Why we think restricting dry-herb-vaporizers is a problematic decision that should be reversed:

1. Cartridge vapes are not easy to access, which leads to people without a prescription resorting to black market dealers, which is risky because their cartridges are often cut with extremely harmful ingredients, such as vitamin E acetate which can and have caused deaths.
2. Banning dry-herb-vapes forces people to go back to smoking or vaping from oil cartridges. Which will be negative for their health.
3. The few devices that have been approved for sale is too expensive for most people, which will lead them to resorting back to using other unhealthier methods of inhaling cannabis.

It is ridiculous to us, that expensive water pipes/bongs are still available for sale everywhere, yet dry-herb-vaporizers are restricted. This encourages more harmful methods of consumption and punishes the healthier ones.
We therefore ask the House to reverse the ban of importing, and the sale of dry-herb-vaporizers, and remove the requirements for a prescription to purchase them.
from five citizens (Petition No. EN6476)
Dental Health

The community dentists have waiting lists of up to 2 years. I think for pensioners or people on dsp and low income who need new dentures they should be more accessible. It is hard not being able to eat, and plus with other health problems they can arise from having no teeth. To go to a private dentist can cost well over $3000, a pensioners cannot afford this. I think up to a certain income some of the services should be bulkbilled for people that are unable to afford their exhorberant fees, it's $383 to remove one tooth, and at the same time will bring community dentists wait list down. Noone should have to go without teeth or broken teeth because they can't afford the fees.

We therefore ask the House to please consider some help for low income and pensioners to be able to get their teeth fixed or get dentures to prevent getting other medical conditions because of poor dental health.
from 13 citizens (Petition No. EN6479)
Corporate Governance

Children's furniture ecommerce company Incy Interiors have failed to fulfill consumer obligations under Australian Consumer Law by not providing goods within a reasonable timeframe. Hundreds of Incy Interiors customers have paid for goods not received. Yet, this business still continues to take orders from new, unwitting customers. If customers have received orders, they are incomplete, damaged, missing parts and/or unsafe for infant/toddler usage. There are over 200 negative reviews on the online review platform, Product Review, and countless negative Google reviews (since deleted by Incy Interiors). Furthermore, there are over 300 members of Impacted by Incy Interiors, a Facebook group established to help aggrieved customers. Incy Interiors have refused refund requests and have instead directed customers to dispute the transaction with their bank. Often, this is not possible because the time since purchasing has exceeded the standard 3-month timeframe. On 30 January 2024, Incy Interiors was liquidated, and the company was sold to Impressive Imports Pty Ltd for between $10,000-$50,000, to "get out of the contract with the major retailer". The business was never commercially valued. The sale document states the purchaser will honour outstanding all customer orders. This has not occurred. The circumstances surrounding this liquidation point to signs of illegal phoenix activity. Impressive Imports has continued to operate utilising the business name 'Incy Interiors'.
We therefore ask the House to bring Incy Interiors' activities to the attention of ASIC, ACCC or other government agencies as appropriate.
from 308 citizens (Petition No. EN6483)
Banking and Financial Services

In June 2020, Best Interest Duty was introduced and this overrides all lenders charging claw backs to finance brokers. Claw backs are no longer relevant and occurs during the term of the loan when the lender cannot price match competitors so clients refinance or may sell the property. Banks will take up to 100% of the upfront commission off the finance broker which sees them unpaid for the loan and out of pocket for their time and expenses. Lenders are looking to reduce the commission payable to finance brokers if claw backs are no longer payable. Lenders are creating online products that finance brokers cannot write, finance brokers won't get paid, with finance brokers not allowed certain loans for themselves. Now banks offer cash backs to get clients and record extremely high profits, but punishing finance brokers on payment for services? No other business provides a service and doesn't get paid for it?
We therefore ask the House to :
1. Remove claw backs being charged to finance brokers immediately for services rendered.
2. Refund any claw backs charged to finance brokers since origination of Best Interest Duty
3. Allow all loan products to be offered by finance brokers to clients including finance brokers themselves.
4. Referred clients taking out additional products with that lender, are to contact the broker to check under Best Interest Duty and paid accordingly.
from 2,100 citizens (Petition No. EN6484)
Medicare

We, the undersigned, believe that adding hypnotherapy to the MBS is crucial amidst the current mental health care crisis. 17% of Australians experience anxiety disorders and depression impacts 1 in 7. Accessible and effective treatments are urgently needed.
Hypnotherapy, performed by well trained professional members of reputable regulatory Association's, offers rapid. significant relief.
Meta analysis research studies show hypnosis reduced anxiety more than 79% of control participants, and depression symptoms improved more than 76% of control participants in just a few sessions.

Hypnotherapy provides fast, effective options, to improve mental health outcomes and ease the current burden on healthcare services. Including hypnotherapy in the MBS is a strategic decision that benefits the Government, families, the community, and Hypnotherapists.

For Government, it means addressing the escalating mental health crisis efficiently, potentially reducing long-term healthcare costs by providing early, effective interventions for conditions such as anxiety and depression.

For families, it offers accessible and affordable mental health support, fostering healthier and more resilient households. The community at large benefits by having access to a more diverse range of therapeutic options, creating improved collective well-being.

Hypnotherapists may service a broader population, including those on mental health care plans. This more collaborative approach ensures clients will get therapy their Doctors' recommend, and this inclusivity can lead to better mental health outcomes across Australia.
It's fiscally responsible, creating a more supported community, ultimately contributing to a healthier, more productive society.
We therefore ask the House to include Hypnotherapy in the Medicare Benefits Scheme.
from 1,502 citizens (Petition No. EN6485)
Family Law

Child support is currently based on an idealistic family model instead of reality where individual single parents must support children. The existing model as noted by experts in their field penalises the primary income earner and doesn't provide equity into financially supporting the children. Disparity then leads to a lack of long-term earning potential as the existing model exaggerates this over time showing that the primary income earner will eventually pay 100% of the raising costs.
A new model needs to be created where it looks at the cost of living for individual single parents raising their children not the current combined "perfect dual income family" scenario.
It needs to take into account 50/50 custody for all living and expenses should also negate payments completely.

We therefore ask the House to conduct a royal commission into a new model of calculation, review other countries methods and how we can best establish a productive model where parents can continue to maximize their earning potential without penalty to provide the best lifestyle for their children.
from 24 citizens (Petition No. EN6489)
COVID-19: Vaccination

The mRNA Covid-19 vaccines cause elevated IgG4 in the blood, which basically shuts down the body's immune system or lowers its efficiency. Taking antioxidants whilst having elevated IgG4 levels cause turbocancers. People need a yearly blood test to see if they're at risk of turbocancers.
We therefore ask the House to pass a law to make IgG4 testing mandatory for mRNA jabbers each year.
from four citizens (Petition No. EN6491)
COVID-19: Vaccination

We now better understand why C19 mRNA jabbers are getting turbocancers. It's because of the mRNA vaccine elevating PD-L1 levels in cells, which mean the immune system doesn't kill the cell displaying the PD-L1.
Poor health, poor diets, genetics, poor immune function (ie: lack of vitamin D), elevated IgG4 & now elevated PD-L1 levels in mRNA jabbers create the perfect environment for cancers & illnesses.
We therefore ask the House to investigate how to better screen the mRNA jabbers for elevated levels of PD-L1 & then pass a law to mandate that screening.
from two citizens (Petition No. EN6493)
Migration
Australia is quickly approaching a dangerous and unsustainable living crisis driven by our large amount of migration we allow into the country.

Housing prices have shot up to an astonishing amount in the last few years simply due to supply and demand, one of these demands being allowing to many migrants into the country buying up homes and keeping everyday Aussies from being able to own their own homes and forced to pay high rental prices which the median income population cannot afford.

Looking at the history of circumstances like this we can see that Canada is going through a similar thing where the current population is comprised of 20% migrants! Out of a population of 39 million that's 8 million homes that actual citizens cannot own.
Australia built a total of 212,879 homes in 2022-2023 but in 2022 our net migration increased to over 400 thousand people once restrictions were eased.

The amount of Australian births we had in 2022 being 302,990 and I understand these aren't adults buying homes but they will be, you don't have to be a mathematician to understand the numbers but clearly there will not be enough homes for everybody.

We therefore ask the House to cull the amount of migrants and students with visas allowed into Australia to give the Australian born a chance at owning a home which is a right of every Australian who works and pays taxes.
Housing shouldn't be a luxury but a right to everyone who works hard and is born in Australia
from 66 citizens (Petition No. EN6494)
Substance Abuse: Nitrous Oxide

nitrous oxide AKA nangs a party drug are being used for drug purposes more then what they should be sold for. A lot of young nsw citizens end up in hospital, mental hospital, or even death requesting these canisters get banned unless for ligit legal purposes.
We therefore ask the House to ban all nitrous oxide canisters being sold especially if known it's for wrong reasons, there unsafe dangerous and life threatening.
from three citizens (Petition No. EN6495)
Occupied Palestinian Territories

We are kindly asking the Albanese government and other members of the House of Representatives to take into deep consideration of recognising the state of Palestine, amidst the current crisis in Gaza. As of the 24th of July 2024, over 30,000 innocent Palestinians have been killed and over 80,000 maimed. We ask the Albanese government to join the other 145 members of the United Nations to have Australia join in the recognition of a Palestinian state.

Furthermore, we ask that the Government to consider placing sanctions on Israel's brutal approach to this conflict and hold Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu accountable for breaching multiple international human rights violations.

Finally, we ask that there be immediate humanitarian aid sent to the civilians Gaza, as they have suffered food shortages, severe medical injuries, lack of electricity, lack of treatment, inability to access clean water, etc.
We therefore ask the House to ,
- To pass legislation recognising the State of Palestine
- End Military and arms trade with Israel
- Send immediate humanitarian aid to civilians in Gaza such as:
—Food security
—Medical assistance
—Shelter and Housing
- Show support for peace initiatives
- Place sanctions on Israel for multiple breaches of international law
from 38 citizens (Petition No. EN6497)

subdebateinfo.title: National Redress Scheme for Institutional Child Sexual Abuse

p.span: National Redress Scheme for Institutional Child Sexual Abuse
We Demand the Following from Federal Governments.

1.Dual State Victims of Sexual, physical and psychological abuse redress payment be doubled, Backdated and reviewed because the abuse and crime was committed by Separate state governments, not single payments as offered under the current scheme.
2.Victims cost be Separate to Lawyers fees who chose personal claims.
3.investigation into unethical lawyers/law firms who overcharge and drag claimants cases out for their financial Benefits." This was the governments pledge but ignored"
3a.Lawyers who have dragged cases out longer than 2 years to reimburse victims for overcharging. and held for Fraud.

4.Redress Payments Lifted in line with today's Monetary claims. From a cap of $150 thousand to an increase of $300.thousand for sexual abuse and $200 thousand for any physical or physiological abuse endured over decades. These Payment to include topping up the Monetary amount already paid to Victims who were forced or bullied into taking what they were offered.

5.Abuse Claims Not limited to claims only committed in institutions, But to the abuse of power delivered by states to victims from authoritarian organizations instructor's or otherwise while under State Control.
We therefore ask the House to Moreover

i/We call on our Australian state and federal government officials to launch an investigation into this matter immediately. We demand fairness in compensation for all victims of institutional abuse including over charged lawyers costs returned to victims.
from 50 citizens (Petition No. EN6498)
Television Advertising
The home shopping adverts are too frequent and are significantly impacting the mental health of Australians. They have their own channels, let them advertise there
We therefore ask the House to amend the television advertising act to restrict home shopping adverts to home shopping channels only
from one citizen (Petition No. EN6499)
Aviation Industry
REX Airlines have entered into voluntary administration. This is the second airline this year that has failed at breaking into the duopoly of the airline business.
If REX is to fold as an airline qantas and virgin will have free reign to put there prices up to whatever they want.
It is a clear problem in the airline industry in Australia that the duopoly has almost complete control, with this every day Australians literally pay the price.

REX services many regional towns across the country that other Airlines do not service, without REX these towns will now be left no suitable means of transport to and from critical services such as hospitals, without spending hours in a car, such hours that many are not able to do.
A government ran airline would provide security for many regional towns across the country.
It will also help keep the duopoly currently in the airline industry in check, by ensuring there is always fair competition.

Buying REX will be a much cheaper option in the long run for the government, as opposed to not having an airline for many regional towns and needing to foot the ongoing bill for transport, or providing a simple bailout which may or may not succeed.
Rex already has the resources, procedures, and staff needed for an airline, what Australia needs is for rex to simply be ran as a government service.
We therefore ask the House to buy rex Airlines, and provide airline public transport for all Australians.
from seven citizens (Petition No. EN6500)
Judiciary
The introduction of a Federal Judicial Commission is needed to examine complaints made about Federal Judges.
The Australian Government has announced and welcomes the Australian Law Reform Commission (ALRC) Report 138, Without Fear or Favour: Judicial Impartiality and the Law on Bias.

A majority of the 14 recommendations that were directed to the federal courts for consideration and action, namely the High Court of Australia, Federal Court of Australia and Federal Circuit and Family Court of Australia.

The Attorney-General, the Hon Mark Dreyfus KC MP, announced on 17 January 2023 the "Scoping the Establishment of a Federal Judicial Commission" with approx 57 submissions were received during that consultation process which ended on 21 February 2023.
The Australian Government has made declarations to support the proposal of an independent Federal Judicial Commission, and yet no action or decisions have been made to date.

This process will restore the administration of justice for all Australians, not only ensuring that justice is both done and seen to be done and the fundamental principles of procedural fairness, including that decision-makers must be independent and impartial.

We therefore ask the House to introduce an independent Federal Judicial Commission at no cost to the applicant, and requests of self-recusal of Judges should be independently reviewed by a third-party member as opposed to the current process available.
from 37 citizens (Petition No. EN6501)
Taxation: Alcohol

The Aussie alcohol tax has increased 71 times and will increase again this August. It is indexed to go up every 6 months. This excise urgently needs to be reviewed as it is hurting small businesses, many of which are still suffering from the effects of lockdowns.

We therefore ask the House to review this excise and halt any future increases to allow, small breweries, distilleries to thrive in our communities. Many businesses and music venues are closing their doors, unable to survive with the drop of patrons due to the costs associated to going for a beer.
from 93 citizens (Petition No. EN6504)
Universities
-Indexation disproportionately impacts younger generations who did not have the privilege of free education.
- Applying Indexation to study fees makes no sense as the education received was a point in time cost.

- Low—Middle Income earners will be disproportionately impact. Higher income earners will have access to the financial resources to voluntarily contribute more to their HECs and as such can avoid years of indexation.
- The cost of living has risen by 4% in the year of 2024. Indexation has inequitable impacts on individuals from a lower socio economic background.
- The government agreed to spend $386 Billion on Submarines, I think you can scrap Indexation.
We therefore ask the House to
End indexation indefinitely.
from 70 citizens (Petition No. EN6508)
Election of Members and Senators
The preference system for election is one sided
We therefore ask the House to abolish preference system.

Make politicians go out earn the right to be there in parliament at moment they do nothing make deals to get a seat. The people don't even get a chance to ask questions of candidates . politicians should earn the right to govern not be given free ride.
from 10 citizens (Petition No. EN6514)
International Relations: Australia and Syria

Lifting sanctions on Syria could significantly improve the lives of ordinary Syrians who are suffering due to the economic hardships imposed by these measures. Sanctions often restrict access to essential goods, medical supplies, and economic opportunities, exacerbating the humanitarian crisis. By removing these sanctions, Australia could help facilitate the flow of humanitarian aid, support economic recovery, and promote stability in the region. Additionally, lifting sanctions could encourage diplomatic engagement and foster a more constructive dialogue aimed at resolving the ongoing conflict.
We therefore ask the House to lift the sanctions on the Syrian people, who have endured immense suffering for the past 13 years.
from six citizens (Petition No. EN6516)
Human Rights: Bangladesh

Members of and authorities acting under instructions of the ruling Awami League Government in Bangladesh, including its student wing Bangladesh Chatra League (BCL), have brutally cracked down on young students peacefully protesting for their legitimate rights against discriminatory treatments in education and employment. According to credible international media reports, within two weeks since 17 July 2024 more than 200 young people including 16 children have been killed, thousands injured, almost 10,000 arrested and about 61,000 charged with various offences in Bangladesh. Our appeal to the Australian Government committed to human rights, democracy and rule of law is to take urgent actions including by way of imposing individual sanctions on perpetrators of the regime in Bangladesh to adhere to international law and human rights.
We therefore ask the House to authorise and request the Australian Government to
A. Call on the Bangladesh Government to immediately release all arbitrarily detained students and/or their family members;
B. Demand that the Bangladesh Government conduct independent and transparent investigations into all alleged abuses of power during the recent student protests;
C. Impose Magnitsky-style sanctions on targeted individuals of the Bangladesh regime on account of involvement in crimes against humanity in Bangladesh;
D. List Bangladesh Chatra League (BCL) as a terrorist organisation; and
E. Refer the alleged perpetrators of the Bangladesh regime to the International Criminal Court for investigation on account of crimes against humanity.
from two citizens (Petition No. EN6517)
Skilled Migration
The processing of 186 visas is taking years in many cases.
During this time immigrants face many issues:
- In some cases stuck with abusive employers who use the visa as a means to manipulate them
- Unable to get home loans or any long term finance
- Unable to get local life insurance
- Partners can't find better paying employment because employers insist on permanent visas
- Pay nearly double in most cases for tertiary education for their children
- Financial hardship due to having to re-do documentation already provided to Home Affairs, but now deemed to have "expired", such as medical tests and police clearance certificates
- Emotional stress and anxiety due to all the above

In many cases these employees are forced to sign agreements with their employers to stay with them for 2 years after the date of the grant, but the grant can take up to 2 years in some cases in and of itself, meaning that an employee can be stuck with an abusive employer for 4 or more years in some cases.
This puts skilled migrants in a difficult position, where they want to integrate and start their lives in Australia, but are unable to do so. It puts severe stress on mental health for many.

We therefore ask the House to employ additional workers at Home Affairs to urgently clear this backlog, especially for those waiting for 12 months or more, and finish processing existing applications before changing priorities in future.
from 323 citizens (Petition No. EN6518)
Human Rights: Bangladesh

Bangladesh is facing a severe political crisis characterised by widespread human rights abuses, including torture, extrajudicial killings, political persecution, wrongful imprisonment, and the forced disappearance of opposition members. This vulnerability has created a climate of fear among citizens, especially the students of Bangladesh, severely curtailing their democratic right to support opposition parties. Moreover, the ongoing suppression of political freedom is destabilising the country and we aim to highlight the urgent need for international intervention to address these violations and restore democratic integrity. The students in Bangladesh, that are currently partaking in the unjust human right violences forced upon them, deserve justice and support.
Furthermore, as an Australian Bangladeshi student, I, and many others feel guilty. The Bengali students deserve justice and the student quota system should be reformed.

We therefore ask the House to encourage immediate action to end the violence against students in Bangladesh, specifically addressing the government's role under Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina. Likewise, we also call upon international bodies and human rights organizations to pressure Sheikh Hasina's administration to cease these abuses, safeguard students' rights, and restore democratic freedoms as well as demanding reforms in the quota system.
from two citizens (Petition No. EN6519)
Fair Work Commission
The Fair Work Commission has failed to uphold the rule of law and through its actions has and continues to actively corrupt the legal system and undermine Australian democracy.

Fair Work Commissioners who are appointed by Ministers from Parliament and given privilege's are not conducting themselves in a manner worthy of their standings and abusing their positional powers by denying the Australian public justice.
The Australian Public has lost trust and confidence in the Fair Work Commission and this is leading the public to take the law into their own hands.
The Fair Work Commission has failed in its primary aim of maintaining harmony in the workplace between employers and employees.

The Fair Work Commission is heavily biased with total disregard to impartiality, it is suppressing evidence, manipulating information and openly practicing favors. The Fair Work Commission is Fair only in name not in substance.
We therefore ask the House to change the name of the Fair Work Commission to Favors Work Commission as this is the true reflection in light of the Commissions conduct.
from six citizens (Petition No. EN6522)
Human Rights: Bangladesh
Dear Penny Wong and Tony Burke,

We, the residents of Macarthur Heights, a suburb in Campbelltown, NSW 2560, are initiating this petition to express our deep concern over the severe human rights violations being committed by the autocratic regime of Sheikh Hasina in Bangladesh.
In light of the ongoing crisis, many corrupt police officers, high-ranking officials, political figures, and their families are reportedly attempting to flee Bangladesh to escape accountability.
Given your position and responsibility to influence our nation's stance on global issues, I urgently request that you bring this matter before Parliament and advocate for the Government.
We therefore ask the House to
A. Revoke all visas previously issued to Bangladeshi police officers, high-ranking officials, and political members of Sheikh Hasina's regime, along with their family members.
B. Suspend the issuance of any new visas to Bangladeshi police officers, high-ranking officials, and political members of the regime and their families.
C. Issue a strong condemnation of the actions of the current Bangladeshi government to reaffirm Australia's commitment to human rights and justice.
from two citizens (Petition No. EN6525)

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Veterans' Affairs: Allied Health Rebates

p.span: Department of Veterans' Affairs: Allied Health Rebates
The scheduled fee for DVA patients to receive treatment at physiotherapy private clinics in Australia is around $73.
Nearly 20 years ago, this amount was above $50.
Indexation of fees has not kept up with increasing costs of doing business.

Data the Australian Physiotherapy Association collected in 2023 shows 26% of physiotherapists in private practice have already stopped or limited providing services to DVA clients, and a further 45% will likely cease DVA services.
91% of physiotherapy clinic owners state that the DVA rebate does not allow them to sustainably continue providing care for Veterans.
Andrew Wilkie gave a speech on this matter to Parliament in early 2024, highlighting concerns of physiotherapy clinic owners.
The Australian Physiotherapy Association (APA) have met with the Federal Minister for DVA, the Hon Matt Keogh, but no positive actions have been taken.
Most DVA clients seeking physiotherapy services are also unaware of the magnitude of this issue.
Physiotherapy clinic owners are being punished by poor Government pricing and are silently going broke treating DVA clients.

We therefore ask the House to consider legislating the increase of the fee paid to private practice physiotherapy clinics to be given parity to two very similar professions in Occupational Therapy and Podiatry, both of whom receive significantly higher fees per service to treat DVA clients.

Current rebates for a minimum 20 minute consultation in rooms in a private physiotherapy clinic in Australia are $73.30, while for Occupational Therapy the rebate for a comparable consultation is $127.80 and for Podiatry $92.35 for a minimum 15 minute consultation.
from 846 citizens (Petition No. EN6526)
Family and Partner Migration

We urgently call on the Australian Government to reduce extended partner visa processing times. Families are struggling, individuals live in isolation, and women 35+ face delays in starting families. Immediate action is needed to reunite loved ones and support mental health.

We therefore ask the House to take swift, decisive action to cut partner visa processing times and review each case individually. Families are suffering, individuals are isolated, and women 35+ face critical delays in starting families. Immediate and compassionate intervention is essential.
from 180 citizens (Petition No. EN6527)
Parliamentary Standards

It is clear that many politicians lie to receive votes and once in power, not only continue to lie but gaslight us. In fact, it is perfectly legal for political advertising in Australia to lie. Enough is enough. We demand real democracy, we demand that all politicians are held accountable with their words, including political advertising, and therefore their actions. This country is being destroyed physically and emotionally because of lies, greed and corruption. The public demands truth and integrity from leaders.

We therefore ask the House to bring forth legislation that will disqualify members of parliament and any candidates found guilty of deliberately misleading the public. Whether it be political advertising, social media posts or any other form of media and public broadcasting. Politicians and political parties must be held accountable.
from 102 citizens (Petition No. EN6530)
Animal Welfare
Key Issues:

1. Funding Shortage and Euthanasia: Veterinary hospitals are routinely faced with the difficult choice of either treating wildlife or managing their limited financial resources. This often results in euthanasia, a decision made out of financial necessity rather than medical judgment.

2. Mental Health Impact: The economic pressures and ethical dilemmas faced by veterinary staff take a significant psychological toll. The veterinary industry already has one of the highest suicide rates, and the additional strain of inadequate funding exacerbates this crisis.

3. Threat to Wildlife Conservation: In Australia, hundreds of wildlife species require emergency care annually. Without government support, veterinary hospitals are at risk of losing the ability to provide essential services, jeopardising both wildlife populations and the sustainability of veterinary practices.

4. Government Commitment to Wildlife Conservation: While the government claims a commitment to wildlife conservation, there is a gap between words and actions. The increasing rate of wildlife extinction demands tangible support for those on the front lines—the veterinary hospitals.
We therefore ask the House to * Allocate funding to veterinary hospitals and practices that treat wildlife patients.
* Support the development and operational costs of specialised wildlife care facilities, such as the proposed hospital at the Hills Wildlife Sanctuary.
* Provide ongoing financial resources to ensure these facilities can offer comprehensive care without jeopardising their financial stability or compromising services for domestic patients.
from 345 citizens (Petition No. EN6532)

PETITIONS
Responses
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (16:36): by leave—I present 25 ministerial responses to petitions previously presented:
Environment
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 7 November 2022 referring a copy of Petition EN4145, a 10-point plan to protect, restore and sustainably manage lands, seas, habitats and species. Due to a technical error, I did not receive your correspondence at the time it was sent, and I apologise sincerely for the delay in my response. The Australian Government is taking action and providing national leadership on climate change and environmental protection, much of which addresses the 10 points in Petition EN4145. I have outlined this in detail below.

The Government is committed to creating a Nature Positive Australia in which nature is being repaired and regenerated rather than continuing to decline. In December 2022, the Government released the Nature Positive Plan: betterfor the environment, better for business. This sets out the Government's commitment to reform Australia's environmental laws to better protect, restore and manage our unique environment.

The Threatened Species Action Plan 2022-2032 provides a pathway to protect, manage, and restore Australia's threatened species and important natural places. Implementation of the plan will be supported by a range of targeted investments to reverse environmental decline. The Government has committed more than $450 million to threatened species recovery, including under the Saving Native Species Program, the Natural Heritage Trust and the National Environmental Science Program.

The Government has set a target to protect and conserve 30 per cent of Australia's landmass and 30 per cent of Australia's marine areas by 2030. In June 2023, Environment Ministers agreed to develop a national 30 by 30 roadmap to provide an overarching framework and pathway for achieving the national 30 per cent land target. The Government is working closely with state and territory governments, alongside public consultation, to develop the roadmap.

The Government is committed to safeguarding the Murray-Darling Basin for future generations through implementation of the Basin Plan 2012 (Cth). I introduced a Bill to Parliament to support implementation and the legislation was passed. The Water Amendment (Restoring Our Rivers) Act 2023 made changes to the Water Act 2007 and Basin Plan to provide more options, more time, more funding, and more accountability to deliver the Basin Plan in full. This is essential to protect our river ecosystems from further environmental collapse, and to save our native animals from extinction.

As part of the October 2022 Budget, the Government announced $1.1 billion for the next phase of the National Heritage Trust (NHT). This funding will continue to sup[port the sustainable management of Australia's natural resources as well as local and long-term environmental, sustainable agriculture and indigenous outcomes. The NHT includes $302.1 million for the Climate-Smart Agriculture Program which will support farmers in several ways, including to adopt climate-smart practices and build climate resilience.

The Government is developing a new National Urban Policy which includes a shared vision for sustainable growth in cities and suburbs, that has been committed to by all Australian Governments. The Policy will address key challenges including adaptation to physical risks such as those posed by climate change. In their June 2024 meeting, Commonwealth, state, and territory Building Ministers confirmed their commitment to climate resilience and discussed measures to assist the transition to net zero in the built environment.
Thank you for referring a copy of the petition to me.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Environment and Water, Ms Plibersek
Taxation
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN4246 to double the Meal Entertainment Card salary packaging maximum limit for aged care and disability workers. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

Fringe benefits tax (FBT) plays an important role in maintaining the fairness and integrity of Australia's tax system. It places employees with access to fringe benefits on a more even footing with employees whose renumeration consists entirely of salary or wages.

FBT concessions are available to certain public benevolent institutions exempting them from FBT on fringe benefits up to a grossed-up per employee limit of $30,000, and a further $5,000 specifically allocated to salary packaged meal entertainment or entertainment facility leasing benefits.

There are a limited number of FBT exemptions and concessions. FBT exemptions add complexity to the FBT law and come at a cost to revenue, and requests to the Government for new or extended exemptions must always be considered alongside other Government priorities and alternative ways of delivering direct support.

As the principal funder of the aged care sector, the Government has committed to provide funding to support the increases to award wages from the Aged Care Work Value Case. The Government has already provided $11.3 billion for an interim wage increase of 15 per cent for aged care workers from 30 June 2023 and has committed to funding the Stage 3 decision that will provide further award wage increases of up to 28.5 per cent (inclusive of the interim decision).
I trust that this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Treasurer, Dr Chalmers
Environment
Dear Chair
Thank you for your referral of 25 July 2023 of a petition regarding geoengineering concerns (EN4406). I regret the time it has taken to respond.

The Australian Government is aware of geoengineering concerns, their association with 'chemtrails' and their prevalence on internet websites. These theories often suggest that the trails seen behind high level aircraft are the result of the deliberate spraying of chemical or biological agents.

The observed phenomenon is actually caused by condensation trails or 'contrails' produced by high level aircraft. These contrails, or long streams of cloud, are formed when hot engine exhaust containing water vapor, carbon dioxide, and small amounts of particles, mixes with cold surrounding air. Under the right conditions contrails can last for hours while growing to several kilometres in width and 200 to 400 metres in height. There is no evidence that contrails are harmful to human health or the environment, although they can lead to increased cloud formation.

Additional information about contrails and other emissions from an aircraft and their impact on the environment and climate is available from the US Environmental Protection Agency website at epa.gov/sites/default/files/2016-10/documents/afd-051013-001.pdf and the Air Services Australia website at www.airservicesaustralia.com/about-us/about-our-operations/condensation-trails.
Thank you again for your correspondence.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Environment and Water, Ms Plibersek
Baw Baw Frog
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 7 November 2022 regarding Petition EN4441 in which signatories outlined concerns about the impact of the amphibian chytrid fungus on the Baw Baw frog.
Chytrid fungus is the principal threat to amphibians in Australia having been directly implicated in the extinction of at least 4 species and the dramatic decline of least 10 other species.

In 2019, the Baw Baw frog was included in the Critically Endangered category of the threatened species list under the Environmental Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (EPBC Act). Conservation Advice for the species identifies chytridiomycosis, an infectious disease caused by chytrid, as the main threat to the recovery of the species, together with habitat loss and degradation. In 2002, Infection of amphibians with chytrid fungus resulting in chytridiomycosis was listed as a Key Threatening Process under the EPBC Act. To address this threat, the first Threat Abatement Plan for infection of amphibians with chytrid fungus resulting in chytridiomycosis was created in 2006. A subsequent Threat Abatement Plan was made in 2016, and this Plan is now under review for possible further update.

The Threat Abatement Plan for chytrid fungus brings together information and priorities for chytrid-related management and research. It has also helped to promote and prioritise awareness raising and research into chytrid. The review of the current Theat Abatement Plan has been undertaken with multiple experts and other stakeholders. Any updates to the Threat Abatement Plan will involve public consultation and assessment of research needs and priorities.
Thank you again for bringing this petition to my notice.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Environment and Water, Ms Plibersek
Cryptocurrency
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN4470 regarding recent legislative amendments that clarified that bitcoin is not a foreign currency for Australian tax purposes.

The amendments were necessary after the Legislative Assembly of the Republic of El Salvador recognised bitcoin as an unrestricted legal tender by legislative decree which took effect on 7 September 2021. An unintended consequence was the potential that bitcoin may be a 'foreign currency' for the purposes of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 due to its status as a legal tender in El Salvador. This is inconsistent with the policy intent—bitcoin and other similar digital currencies were never intended to be foreign currencies for Australian income tax purposes.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Treasurer, Dr Chalmers
Climate Change
Dear Chair

Thank you for the referral of petition EN4671. The petition asks the House of Representatives to create a new offence under the Public Interest Disclosure Act 2013 (PID Act) that would criminalise false and misleading statements made by public officials about climate change.

The PID Act framework promotes the transparency, integrity and accountability of the Commonwealth public sector. It enables public officials to disclose information about suspected wrongdoing by another public official or by an Australia Government agency, and requires disclosures to be properly investigated and managed. It also provides those public officials with the assurance that they will be protected from adverse consequences relating to their disclosure if it is made in accordance with the requirements of the PID Act.

A public interest disclosure about alleged false or misleading statements, where those statements would constitute disclosable conduct under the Act, would be investigated under the PID Act or other relevant investigative framework. It would not be appropriate to include a criminal offence in the PID Act for false and misleading statements made by public officials. This would be inconsistent with the objects of the PID Act framework to encourage the disclosure and investigation of wrongdoing in the Commonwealth public sector.

There are existing legislative obligations with which Australian Public Service employees and agency heads must comply, including the APS Code of Conduct in section 13 of the Public Service Act 1999 (Cth). Among other things, the Code of Conduct provides that APS employees:
must behave honestly and with integrity in connection with APS employment
must not provide false or misleading information in response to a request for information that is made for official purposes in connection with the employee's APS employment and
must at all times behave in a way that upholds the APS Values, which include that the APS demonstrates leadership, is trustworthy, and acts with integrity, in all it does.
Possible sanctions for breaches of the APS Code of Conduct are set out in section 15 of the Public Service Act, and range from a reprimand to termination of employment.

Additionally, the National Anti-Corruption Commission has the power to investigate issues of serious or systemic corrupt conduct in the Australian Government public sector. The Government is not proposing to introduce new criminal offences in relation to conduct mentioned in the petition in the National Anti-Corruption Commission Act 2022.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Dreyfus
Grocery Prices
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN5209 on supermarkets profiteering during the current cost of living crisis. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

The Government is committed to ensuring that the right regulatory settings are in place to support a vibrant and sustainable food and grocery industry in Australia, and has initiated a number of initiatives to support this.

The Government is committed to ensuring that the right regulatory settings are in place to support a vibrant and sustainable food and grocery industry in Australia, and has initiated a number of initiatives to support this.

On 10 January 2024, the Government announced the appointment of Dr Craig Emerson to lead an independent review of the Food and Grocery Code of Conduct (the C ode). The final report of the independent review was released on 24 June 2024, making 11 recommendations to ensure the Code promotes and supports good faith commercial dealings between supermarkets, wholesalers, and their suppliers. The recommendations included making the Code mandatory and the introduction of heavy penalties to deter non- compliance. On the same day, the Government released its response to the Review supporting the recommendations of Dr Emerson's final report. The Government will formally consult on the new Food and Grocery Code of Conduct soon, before it is anticipated to be in place later in the year.

On 1 February 2024, the Treasurer directed the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) to undertake a 12-month price inquiry into the supermarket sector, to ensure Australians are paying a fair price for their everyday groceries. Under the direction, the inquiry will consider the pricing practices of supermarkets and the relationship between wholesale, farmgate, and retail prices. An issues paper was published on 29 February 2024. An interim report was provided to the Australian Government on 30 August 2024, and will be released in due course. The final report is due to the Australian Government by 28 February 2025.

The Government has also funded respected consumer group CHOICE to provide price transparency and comparison reports on a quarterly basis for three years. The reports will help consumers make more informed choices so they can get cheaper prices at the checkout. The first quarterly report was released on 20 June 2024. The petitioners can access a copy of the report at https://www.choice.com.au/cheapestgroceries
I trust this information will be of assistance to your petitioners.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Competition, Charities and Treasury, Dr Leigh
Economy
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN5281 on the RBA lowering the cash rate. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

I acknowledge that each increase to interest rates has been very challenging for Australians who are already facing difficult circumstances. Households are under pressure from higher cost of living and higher interest rates.

The Government does not intervene in the decisions taken by the independent Reserve Bank, which aims to keep inflation between 2 and 3 per cent a year. The recent Review of the Reserve Bank recommended that the current inflation targeting approach should remain the preferred operational framework to pursue low and stable inflation and full employment.
The Government's economic plan is focused on tackling inflation and providing responsible cost of living relief.

The Government has legislated tax cuts for all Australian taxpayers, which commenced from 1 July 2024. To ease pressure on low- and middle-income Australian households, changes made by the Government deliver bigger tax cuts for them in a way that does not add to the inflation outlook. The Government has also increased the Medicare levy low-income thresholds for singles, families, seniors and pensioners from 1 July 2023.

The Government is also delivering cost-of-living relief to help ease pressure on households and businesses, including energy bill relief for all households and eligible small businesses, further increasing Commonwealth Rent Assistance, making medicines cheaper, and reducing student debt. This builds on the ongoing relief provided in the 2022-23 October Budget and 2023-24 Budget, which includes making it easier to see a bulk billing doctor, making childcare cheaper, and increasing JobSeeker and other working age and student payments.

The Government's energy bill relief and the increase to Commonwealth Rent Assistance are expected to directly reduce inflation by half of a percentage point in 2024-25 and are not expected to add to broader inflationary pressures.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Treasurer, Dr Chalmers
